For Release AMs Thursday, Dec. 21
Shakeout In The Automotive Industry
DOC.TEXT: The nation's car market is so suffused with lookalike brands and models that competition increasingly will be forced into pricing, says a professor who has studied the market for three decades. He forecasts competitive pricing over the next few years ``like we've never seen before'' with potentially severe damage to products lines and even to entire manufacturing operations. ``There'll be a shakeout,'' says Professor Eugene Jennings of Michigan State University, an adviser to top corporate executives and an observer of the automotive industry whose opinions are widely sought. ``We go into the 1990s with homogenization of design and style clear across the board,'' said Jennings, who earlier attributed some of General Motors' lost market share to a lack of distinctiveness among its own brands. Now, he says, sameness pervades the whole industry to such an extent that product differences are even too subtle for advertising, being observable only after salesmen call attention to them in the showroom. But getting buyers into the showrooms, particularly for cars with little ``curb appeal,'' is more difficult than ever, Jennings says, especially after two years in which sales were kept strong by drawing from future markets. He says it is unlikely that any one manufacturer intended it this way, but that they reacted in similar conservative ways to a fear of overcapacity in the industry, rather than risk losing share through unacceptable innovations. ``The consequences were too great if they guessed wrong,'' said Jennings in an interview. ``New concepts would have presented too much risk.'' And yet, he suggested, it might take the assumption of such risk to make a breakthrough. The rare market situation already is reflected in advertising where, he says, more and more money is spent simply to ``break through the clutter and confusion,'' and images and themes substitute for product distinctiveness. ``It's almost as if automobiles have become a commodity,'' said Jennings, a business professor and author of many books about the inner workings of corporations. The pricing problem could hardly be more serious, he says, observing that prices are following the same conservative trend, ``a bit above or below the category average _ and be prepared to make a deal.'' While the sameness syndrome exists, he says, it will be difficult for many car lines to sustain premium prices, since customers can easily switch to the ``same'' car made by a different manufacturer. Planning and development also are affected by the syndrome. Big spending in this area always has been risky, if necessary, since a new concept or radical style change might not be accepted. The failure of Ford's Edsel is a monument to that risk, and more recently, says Jennings, photographs of General Motors' Saturn car, a costly effort to rethink the entire production process, were greeted by yawns. In the current market, where sales already have been ``borrowed'' from model years to come, and with large overcapacity in manufacturing operations, the risk is magnified. ``No one can afford to have an Edsel,'' says Jennings. While assumption of that risk might eventually be the only way to dissolve the stalemate, Jennings feels for the time being companies most likely will fight their battle on the pricing front. ``Prices will not hold at premium levels,'' he states.
